display_title.display_title:
Bolivia - Proyecto Carretera
            Abapó-Camiri (antes, Proyecto Carretera Camiri): Evaluación
            del impacto ambiental (Vol. 2)

docna.cdata!:
Bolivia - Abapo-Camiri Highway Project
            (formerly Camiri Road Project) : environmental impact assessment

repnme.cdata!:
Bolivia - Abapo-Camiri Highway Project
            (formerly Camiri Road Project) : environmental impact assessment

0.cdata!:
Explosives; Hazardous waste disposal; Noise
            control; Dust; Greenbelts; Vegetative propagation; Soil
            pollution; Soil reclamation; Water pollution control; Air
            quality management; Emissions control; Wastewater
            collection; Drainage systems; Mulching; Revegetation;
            Ecological balance; Hunting; Aquatic ecoystems

abstracts.cdata!:
This is an environmental assessment of
            the Abapo-Camiri Highway Project (formerly the Camiri Road
            Project), which reconstructs and improves transport
            conditions along a north-south corridor connecting Bolivian
            departments and continuing to Argentina and Paraguay. Some
            negative environmental impacts and their mitigations include
            the following: During construction, decibel levels will be
            reduced in the population centers most sensitive to noise;
            the hours of operation restricted; greenbelts erected; and
            car velocity and horn-blowing limited. To reduce dust and
            emissions caused by vehicles and machinery, the roads will
            be sprayed, oil and other pollutants will not be burned, and
            insulation will be hung in dwellings. Equipment and
            machinery will be operated to comply with air quality and
            noise level standards, including covering transport trucks.
            Solid waste disposal and basic sanitation measures will
            prevent soil contamination. To prevent landslides resulting
            from deforestation and vegetation removal, barricades will
            be erected. Mulching, bundling wood and revegetation will
            avoid erosion and minimize sedimentation. A drainage system
            and protection works will shore up embankments. Compacted
            topsoil will have its natural permeability restored.
            Drainage systems will be dug along river banks only after
            hydraulic analysis. Only minimal quantities of explosives
            will be used at quarries. To protect area fauna, hunting and
            fishing will be prohibited.
